The only time I play Gladiator, really, is when a friend of mine is 
at my house and we are both playing it with the intent to put the 
character of the other to death.

During these games, we've used every character class known to 
Gladiator on each other. Some of them are great duelists. Some of 
them would be best served by surrendering before the battle begins.

Soldiers - Usable for dueling, but tends to lose. Whirl is good for 
fearing the enemy if you're under artillery fire of some sort, but 
doesn't really last long enough to do anything. Disarm requires you 
to get to melee range, which is unlikely in duels. However, 
Boomerang does massive damage at high levels and Charge lets you get 
close enough that your boomerangs hit.

Barbarian - If you give up and stand still, your death will be 
faster.

Elf - If the map has deep, deep woods, you could hide in the woods 
and be really evil/cheap against most classes. Otherwise, Elves are 
only good for setting up "traps" of huge amounts of rocks in maps 
with enclosed areas.

Archer - Much better in open maps, where exploding bolt can be used 
indiscriminately. In enclosed spaces, settle for Barrage. One of the 
most powerful dueling classes, if not the most powerful.

Mage - Freeze Time if you're on Team 1 and your friend won't shout 
at you for it. Otherwise, Warp Space to do damage and Teleport if 
you're about to eat 100 Exploding Bolts.

ArchMage - Their normal attack is insanely powerful. If you're NOT 
opposing a Thief or ArchMage, Summon Elemental to create a level-150 
NPC Elemental is usually instant win. If elementals are coming after 
you, use Mind Control, summon your own, and/or run. Don't try Mind 
Control against a single enemy, though - it will usually just get 
you killed anyway.

Clerics - If there are high-level corpses sitting around on the map, 
feel free to ressurect them. Against undead, I'd assume you could 
Turn them. Otherwise, you have to hope for getting to melee range 
and using Mystic Mace.

Thief - At high levels, Cloak has nearly-infinite duration, which 
makes it a lot harder for the enemy to find you. Poison Cloud can be 
used in enclosed areas to set up traps and Charm can turn those 
level-150 NPC Elementals against the enemy. Bombs, however, are a 
Thief's main weapon, allowing one to do an absurd amount of damage 
if the enemy is caught in a bomb trap. My favorite dueling class.

Druids - I've heard from my friend that Grow Tree is also a death 
spell, but I've never tried it. Protection is utterly useless 
against most forms of attack people will use. Summon, however, is 
great. It summons level-1 faeries that die in one hit... but if they 
hit the enemy, they're stunned forever.

Orc - I suppose you could run at the enemy Howling. Fear explosive 
bolts.

Fire Elemental - Starburst and hope you aren't explosive-bolted to 
death.

Skeletons - Barely better than barbarians, since their special lets 
them dodge. Of course, sometimes they dodge into the line of fire. 
Also, Turn Undead could be bad.

Ghost - Turn Undead could be bad, but all Ghosts can really do is 
fly around Howling and attacking the enemy. Fear explosive bolts.

Faerie - Gets some points since its melee attack is permanent stun 
against high-level characters. Loses them for having nothing except 
melee attacks and flight.

Slime - If you're in the line of attack, killing you three times is 
usually just as easy as killing you once.

And there you have it, my opinion on all of the classes of 
Gladiator. Of course, all of these are biased towards high-level, 
high-stats duels and towards the other player being skilled at the 
game.
